p: Another clear example of marginalized groups facing disparate harm during the pandemic is the country’s incarcerated population of more than two million people.11 During the early months of the pandemic, coronavirus cases in federal and state prisons were almost six times higher than in the general population. Death rates were three times higher (Saloner et al. 2020). It’s also likely that these numbers underestimate the prevalence of coronavirus in prisons, since some aren’t testing or reporting cases at all (Van Beusekom 2020). Similarly, immigrants detained in ICE detention facilitates have faced disproportionate exposure to coronavirus and systemic lack of access to basic measures of protection.12 The disregard that the US government has shown toward the humanity and health of people in prisons, jails, and ICE custody is a human rights atrocity that will stain the country’s history for generations to come.
